main event: A yellow star-like object, 5 or 6 times the size of the North Star, was observed at a very high altitude in Tarrytown, N.Y. on August 9, 1956. It was seen for several minutes and described as hovering and generally moving southward before disappearing around 1:30 a.m.
interesting points: The sighting was reported by a civilian and confirmed by police officers, including one with a commercial pilot's license.
The object was described as yellowish and significantly larger than any star in the sky.
It was observed at a very high altitude and remained in sight for several minutes before disappearing.
The conclusion of the investigating officer was that the sighting was a shooting star, possibly a high altitude balloon, which did not concur with the reporting officer's assessment.
The sighting was significant enough to prompt police headquarters to dispatch patrolman to investigate.
result: prosaic explanation (shooting star, possibly a high altitude balloon)
sighted object: yellow star-like object at a very high altitude
witnesses: civilian, police officers including one with a commercial pilot's license
